qas.question: What percentage of people who've had upper limbs amputated feel phantom pain?
What is the percentage of of phantom pain felt by lower limb amputees?
After six months, what percentage of people who had limbs amputated still felt pain in those limbs?
What may happen with intact body parts if there is continuous pain for a long period?
What may accompany urination for amputees?
What do 54% of upper limb amputees experience?
What do 82% of lower limb amputees experience?
What did 72% of patients experience six days after amputation?
What did 65% of patients report eight months after amputation?

context: The prevalence of <b5_0><b6_0>phantom pain<b6_0/><b5_0/> in upper limb amputees is <a0_0>nearly 82%<a0_0/>, and in lower limb amputees is <a1_0>54%<a1_0/>. One study found that eight days after amputation, 72 percent of patients had <b7_0><b8_0>phantom limb pain<b8_0/><b7_0/>, and six months later, <a2_0>65 percent<a2_0/> reported it. Some amputees experience continuous pain that varies in intensity or quality; others experience several bouts a day, or it may occur only once every week or two. It is often described as shooting, crushing, burning or cramping. If the pain is continuous for a long period, parts of the intact body may <a3_0>become sensitized<a3_0/>, so that touching them evokes pain in the phantom limb, or <a4_0>phantom limb pain<a4_0/> may accompany urination or defecation.
